title: How to Get Rid of a Hickey Fast

steps.title: Choose a cold compress.
steps.content: Choose a cold compress. You can use ice or a cold compress, but be sure to wrap it in a towel. [1] X Research source Or, put a metal spoon in the freezer, and apply the back side of the spoon directly to the site of the hickey.

steps.title: Apply cold compress to the hickey.
steps.content: Apply cold compress to the hickey. Cold helps bruises by reducing swelling and slowing blood circulation. [2] X Trustworthy Source University of Rochester Medical Center Leading academic medical center in the U.S. focused on clinical care and research Go to source Apply the cold compress for 10 to 20 minutes at a time, several times each day. For best results, use cold treatment in the first 24 to 48 hours after acquiring the bruise. [3] X Trustworthy Source University of Rochester Medical Center Leading academic medical center in the U.S. focused on clinical care and research Go to source After icing for 10 to 20 minutes, remove the ice pack for at least 10 minutes before reapplying it as needed. [4] X Trustworthy Source University of Rochester Medical Center Leading academic medical center in the U.S. focused on clinical care and research Go to source

steps.title: Prevent further trauma.
steps.content: Prevent further trauma. Certain activities can cause bruises (including hickies) to swell, which may prolong the healing process. For the first 48 hours after you've gotten a hickey, avoid "traumatic" activities, including: hot showers hot tubs heat packs drinking alcoholic beverages Wondering how to make a hickey go away quickly? Check out what users have to say on wikiHow's “How can I make a hickey go away fast?” forum .

steps.title: Switch to a warm compress.
steps.content: Switch to a warm compress. Ice is only really effective for the first 48 hours. [5] X Trustworthy Source University of Rochester Medical Center Leading academic medical center in the U.S. focused on clinical care and research Go to source After icing the hickey for 48 hours, you'll want to switch to a warm compress for the remainder of your treatment regimen. Ice heals the broken blood vessels, but heat will help increase blood flow to the area. This will facilitate healing and the reabsorption of blood. [6] X Research source Use a hot water bottle or a microwavable heating pad. [7] X Trustworthy Source University of Rochester Medical Center Leading academic medical center in the U.S. focused on clinical care and research Go to source Do not apply heat therapy for longer than 20 minutes at a time. Don't use heat therapy if you have diabetes or poor circulation. [8] X Trustworthy Source University of Rochester Medical Center Leading academic medical center in the U.S. focused on clinical care and research Go to source

steps.title: Massage the bruise.
steps.content: Massage the bruise. In addition to applying a warm compress, massaging a bruise like a hickey can help facilitate blood flow to the site of the injury. [9] X Research source Common methods of massaging a hickey include rubbing it with your hands or applying pressure using: a toothbrush with stiff bristles [10] X Research source a pen cap [11] X Research source the cap from a tube of chapstick [12] X Research source

steps.title: Treat the skin.
steps.content: Treat the skin. Icing, heating, and massaging the skin will all help the bruise heal, but you may want to treat the skin in order to make the physical mark disappear more quickly. No skin treatment will provide instant results, but will help speed up the healing process. [13] X Research source Common skin treatments include: aloe vera [14] X Research source Arnica salve [15] X Research source Preparation H [16] X Research source taking vitamins C, E, and K supplements [17] X Research source [18] X Expert Source Alicia Ramos Skincare Professional Expert Interview. 12 June 2019. taking bilberry extract [19] X Research source taking bromelain [20] X Research source

steps.title: Wear your hair down.
steps.content: Wear your hair down. If you have long hair, you can simply wear your hair down to cover up hickies on your neck and shoulders. [21] X Research source Not everyone will have hair long enough to conceal a hickey. Fortunately, if you do not have long hair, there are still plenty of options to cover up your hickey.

steps.title: Apply makeup.
steps.content: Apply makeup. While the bruise from a hickey heals, you may want to cover it up so that it is less visible. Try using concealer, foundation, and/or powder to mask the hickey. [22] X Research source Makeup should be chosen carefully to match your natural skin tone. [23] X Research source In a pinch, you might be able to get away with applying toothpaste to the hickey. This will only work if you have a naturally pale complexion, and is much less efficient than makeup. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Hide the hickey.
steps.content: Hide the hickey. Depending on how you typically dress and what time of year it is, there are many ways you can quickly and easily hide your hickey. The key is hiding the hickey in a way that won't draw attention to it. Try concealing the bruise by wearing: a bandage [25] X Research source a turtleneck [26] X Research source a collard shirt [27] X Research source a scarf [28] X Research source a hooded sweatshirt [29] X Research source a thick, wide necklace [30] X Research source
